column1: FOREWORD|We
column2: of Alcoholics Anonymous
column3: are more than one hundred men and women who have recovered from a seemingly hopeless state of mind and body. To show other alcoholics PRECISELY HOW THEY CAN RECOVER is the main purpose of this book. For them
column4: we think these pages will prove so convincing that no further authentication will be necessary. We hope this account of our experiences will help everyone to better understand the alcoholic. Many do not yet comprehend that he is a very sick person. And besides
column5: we are sure that our new way of living has its advantages for all.

column1: It is important that we remain anonymous because we are too few
column2: at present
column3: to handle the overwhelming number of personal appeals which will result from this publication. Being mostly business or professional folk we could not well carry on our occupations in such an event. We would like it clearly understood that our alcoholic work is an avocation only
column4: so that when writing or speaking publicly about alcoholism
column5: we urge each of our Fellowship to omit his personal name
column6: designating himself instead as "A Member of Alcoholics Anonymous."

column1: Very earnestly we ask the press also
column2: to observe this request
column3: for otherwise we shall be greatly handicapped.

column1: We are not an organization in the conventional sense of the word. There are no fees nor dues whatsoever. The only requirement for membership is an honest desire to stop drinking. We are not allied with any particular faith
column2: sect or denomination
column3: nor do we oppose anyone. We simply wish to be helpful to those who are afflicted.

column1: We shall be interested to hear from those who are getting results from this book
column2: particularly from those who have commenced work with other alcoholics. We shall try to contact such cases.

column1: Inquiry by scientific
column2: medical and religious societies will be welcomed.

column1: ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS~THE DOCTOR'S OPINION|We of Alcoholics Anonymous believe that the reader will be interested in the medical estimate of the plan of recovery described in this book. Convincing testimony must surely come from medical men who have had experience with the sufferings of our members and have witnessed our return to health. A well known doctor
column2: chief physician at a nationally prominent hospital specializing in alcoholic and drug addiction
column3: gave Alcoholics Anonymous this letter:

column1: To Whom It May Concern:
I have specialized in the treatment of alcoholism for many years.
About four years ago I attended a patient who
column2: though he had been a competent business man of good earning capacity
column3: was an alcoholic of a type I had come to regard as hopeless.

column1: In the course of his third treatment he acquired certain ideas concerning a possible means of recovery. As part of his rehabilitation he commenced to present his conceptions to other alcoholics
column2: impressing upon them that they must do likewise with still others. This has become the basis of a rapidly growing fellowship of these men and their families. This man and over one hundred others appear to have recovered.

column1: I personally know thirty of these cases who were of the type with whom other methods had failed completely.

These facts appear to be of extreme medical importance; because of the extraordinary possibilities of rapid growth inherent in this group they mark a new epoch in the annals of alcoholism. These men may well have a remedy for thousands of such situations.
You may rely absolutely on anything they say about themselves.
Very truly yours
(Signed)- - - - - M.D.
The physician who
column2: at our request
column3: gave us this letter
column4: has been kind enough to enlarge upon his views in another statement which follows. In this statement he confirms what anyone who has suffered alcoholic torture must believe - that the body of the alcoholic is quite as abnormal as his mind. It does not satisfy us to be told that we cannot control our drinking just because we were maladjusted to life
column5: that we were in full flight from reality
column6: or were outright mental defectives. These things were true to some extent
column7: in fact
column8: to a considerable extent with some of us. But we are sure that our bodies were sickened as well. In our belief
column9: any picture of the alcoholic which leaves out this physical factor is incomplete.

column1: The doctor's theory that we have a kind of allergy to alcohol interests us. As laymen
column2: our opinion as to its soundness may
column3: of course
column4: mean little. But as ex-alcoholics
column5: we can say that his explanation makes good sense. It explains many things for which we cannot otherwise account.

column1: Though we work out our solution on the spiritual plane
column2: we favor hospitalization for the alcoholic who is very jittery or befogged. More often than not
column3: it is imperative that a man's brain be cleared before he is approached
column4: as he has then a better chance of understanding and accepting what we have to offer.

column1: The doctor writes:
The subject presented in this book seems to me to be of paramount importance to those afflicted with alcoholic addiction.
I say this after many years' experience as Medical Director of one of the oldest hospitals in the country treating alcoholic and drug addiction.
There was
column2: therefore
column3: a sense of real satisfaction when I was asked to contribute a few words on a subject which is covered in such masterly detail in these pages.

column1: We doctors have realized for a long time that some form of moral psychology was of urgent importance to alcoholics
column2: but its application presented difficulties beyond our conception. What with our ultra-modern standards
column3: our scientific approach to everything
column4: we are perhaps not well equipped to apply the powers of good that lie outside our synthetic knowledge.

column1: About four years ago one of the leading contributors to this book came under our care in this hospital and while here he acquired some ideas which he put into practical application at once.
Later
column2: he requested the privilege of being allowed to tell his story to other patients here and perhaps with some misgiving
column3: we consented. The cases we have followed through have been most interesting; in fact
column4: many of them are amazing. The unselfishness of these men as we have come to know them
column5: the entire absence of profit motive
column6: and their community spirit
column7: is indeed inspiring to one who has labored long and wearily in this alcoholic field. They believe in themselves
column8: and still more in the Power which pulls chronic alcoholics back from the gates of death.

column1: Of course an alcoholic ought to be freed from his physical craving for liquor
column2: and this often requires a definite hospital procedure
column3: before psychological measures can be of maximum benefit.

column1: We believe
column2: and so suggested a few years ago
column3: that the action of alcohol on these chronic alcoholics is a manifestation of an allergy; that the phenomenon of craving is limited to this class and never occurs in the average temperate drinker. These allergic types can never safely use alcohol in any form at all; and once having formed the habit and found they cannot break it
column4: once having lost their self-confidence
column5: their reliance upon things human
column6: their problems pile up on them and become astonishingly difficult to solve.

column1: Frothy emotional appeal seldom suffices. The message which can interest and hold these alcoholic people must have depth and weight. In nearly all cases
column2: their ideals must be grounded in a power greater than themselves
column3: if they are to re-create their lives.

column1: If any feel that as psychiatrists directing a hospital for alcoholics we appear somewhat sentimental
column2: let them stand with us a while on the firing line
column3: see the tragedies
column4: the despairing wives
column5: the little children; let the solving of these problems become a part of their daily work
column6: and even of their sleeping moments
column7: and the most cynical will not wonder that we have accepted and encouraged this movement. We feel
column8: after many years of experience
column9: that we have found nothing which has contributed more to the rehabilitation of these men than the community movement now growing up among them.

column1: Men and women drink essentially because they like the effect produced by alcohol. The sensation is so elusive that
column2: while they admit it is injurious
column3: they cannot after a time differentiate the true from the false. To them
column4: their alcoholic life seems the only normal one. They are restless
column5: irritable and discontented
column6: unless they can again experience the sense of ease and comfort which comes at once by taking a few drinks - drinks which they see others taking with impunity. After they have succumbed to the desire again
column7: as so many do
column8: and the phenomenon of craving develops
column9: they pass through the well-known stages of a spree
column10: emerging remorseful
column11: with a firm resolution not to drink again. This is repeated over and over
column12: and unless this person can experience an entire psychic change there is very little hope of his recovery.

column1: On the other hand - and strange as this may seem to those who do not understand - once a psychic change has occurred
column2: the very same person who seemed doomed
column3: who had so many problems he despaired of ever solving them
column4: suddenly finds himself easily able to control his desire for alcohol
column5: the only effort necessary being that required to follow a few simple rules.

column1: Men have cried out to me in sincere and despairing appeal: "Doctor
column2: I cannot go on like this! I have everything to live for! I must stop
column3: but I cannot! You must help me!"

column1: Faced with this problem
column2: if a doctor is honest with himself
column3: he must sometimes feel his own inadequacy. Although he gives all that is in him
column4: it often is not enough. One feels that something more than human power is needed to produce the essential psychic change. Though the aggregate of recoveries resulting from psychiatric effort is perhaps considerable
column5: we physicians must admit we have made little impression upon the problem as a whole. Many types do not respond to the ordinary psychological approach.

column1: I do not hold with those who believe that alcoholism is entirely a mental condition. I have had many men who had
column2: for example
column3: worked a period of months on some problem or business deal which was to be settled on a certain date
column4: favorably to them. They took a drink a day or so prior to the date
column5: and then the phenomenon of craving at once became paramount to all other interests so that the important appointment was not met. These men were not drinking to escape; they were drinking to overcome a craving beyond their mental control.

column1: There are many situations which arise out of the phenomenon of craving which cause men to make the supreme sacrifice rather than continue to fight.
The classification of alcoholics seems most difficult
column2: and in much detail is outside the scope of this book. There are
column3: of course
column4: the constitutional psychopaths who are emotionally unstable. We are all familiar with this type. They are always "going on the wagon for keeps." They are over-remorseful and make many resolutions
column5: but never a decision.

column1: Then there are those who are never properly adjusted to life
column2: who are the so-called neurotics. The prognosis of this type is unfavorable.

column1: There is the type of man who is unwilling to admit that he cannot take a drink. He plans various ways of drinking. He changes his brand or his environment. There is the type who always believes that after being entirely free from alcohol for a period of time he can take a drink without danger. There is the manic-depressive type
column2: who is
column3: perhaps
column4: the least understood by his friends
column5: and about whom a whole chapter could be written.

column1: Then there are types entirely normal in every respect except in the effect alcohol has upon them. They are often able
column2: intelligent
column3: friendly people.

column1: All these
column2: and many others
column3: have one symptom in common: they cannot start drinking without developing the phenomenon of craving. This phenomenon
column4: as we have suggested
column5: may be the manifestation of an allergy which differentiates these people
column6: sets them apart as a distinct entity. It has never been
column7: by any treatment with which we are familiar
column8: permanently eradicated. The only relief we have to suggest is entire abstinence.

column1: This immediately precipitates us into a seething caldron of debate. Much has been written pro and con
column2: but among physicians
column3: the general opinion seems to be that most chronic alcoholics are doomed.

column1: What is the solution? Perhaps I can best answer this by relating an experience of two years ago.

About one year prior to this experience a man was brought in to be treated for chronic alcoholism. He had but partially recovered from a gastric hemorrage and seemed to be a case of pathological mental deterioration. He had lost everything worth while in life and was only living
column2: one might say
column3: to drink. He frankly admitted and believed that for him there was no hope. Following the elimination of alcohol
column4: there was found to be no permanent brain injury. He accepted the plan outlined in this book. One year later he called to see me
column5: and I experienced a very strange sensation. I knew the man by name
column6: and partly recognized his features
column7: but there all resemblance ended. From a trembling
column8: despairing
column9: nervous wreck
column10: had emerged a man brimming over with self-reliance and contentment. I talked with him for some time
column11: but was not able to bring myself to feel that I had known him before. To me he was a stranger
column12: and so he left me. More than three years have now passed with no return to alcohol.

column1: When I need a mental uplift
column2: I often think of another case brought in by a physician prominent in New York City. The patient had made his own diagnosis
column3: and deciding his situation hopeless
column4: had hidden in a deserted barn determined to die. He was rescued by a searching party
column5: and
column6: in desperate condition
column7: brought to me. Following his physical rehabilitation
column8: he had a talk with me in which he frankly stated he thought the treatment a waste of effort
column9: unless I could assure him
column10: which no one ever had
column11: that in the future he would have the "will power" to resist the impulse to drink.

column1: His alcoholic problem was so complex
column2: and his depression so great
column3: that we felt his only hope would be through what we then called "moral psychology"
column4: and we doubted if even that would have any effect.

column1: However
column2: he did become "sold" on the ideas contained in this book. He has not had a drink for more than three years. I see him now and then and he is as fine a specimen of manhood as one could wish to meet.

column1: I earnestly advise every alcoholic to read this book through
column2: and though perhaps he came to scoff
column3: he may remain to pray.~BILL'S STORY|War fever ran high in the New England town to which we new
column4: young officers from Plattsburg were assigned
column5: and we were flattered when the first citizens took us to their homes
column6: making us feel heroic. Here was love
column7: applause
column8: war; moments sublime with hilarious intervals. I was part of life at last
column9: and in the midst of the excitement I discovered liquor. I forgot the strong warnings and the prejudices of my people concerning drink. In time we sailed for "Over There". I was very lonely and again turned to alcohol.

column1: We landed in England. I visited Winchester Cathedral. Much moved
column2: I wandered outside. My attention was caught by a doggerel on an old tombstone:

column1: "Here lies a Hampshire Grenadier
Who caught his death
Drinking cold small beer
A good soldier is ne'er forgot
Whether he dieth by musket
Or by pot."
Ominous warning - which I failed to heed.
Twenty-two
column2: and a veteran of foreign wars
column3: I went home at last. I fancied myself a leader
column4: for had not the men of my battery given me a special token of appreciation? My talent for leadership
column5: I imagined
column6: would place me at the head of vast enterprises which I would manage with utmost assurance.

column1: I took a night law course
column2: and obtained employment as investigator for a surety company. The drive for success was on. I'd prove to the world I was important. My work took me about Wall Street and little by little I became interested in the market. Many people lost money - but some became very rich. Why not I? I studied economics and business as well as law. Potential alcoholic that I was
column3: I nearly failed my law course. At one of the finals I was too drunk to think or write. Though my drinking was not yet continuous
column4: it disturbed my wife. We had long talks when I would still her forebodings by telling her that men of genius conceived their best projects when drunk; that the most majestic constructions of philosophic thought were so derived.

column1: By the time I had completed the course
column2: I knew the law was not for me. The inviting maelstrom of Wall Street had me in its grip. Business and financial leaders were my heroes. Out of this alloy of drink and speculation
column3: I commenced to forge the weapon that one day would turn in its flight like a boomerang and all but cut me to ribbons. Living modestly
column4: my wife and I saved $1
column5: 000. It went into certain securities then cheap and rather unpopular. I rightly imagined that they would some day have a great rise. I failed to persuade my broker friends to send me out looking over factories and managements
column6: but my wife and I decided to go anyway. I had developed a theory that most people lost money in stocks through ignorance of markets. I discovered many more reasons later on.

column1: We gave up our positions and off we roared on a motorcycle
column2: the sidecar stuffed with tent
column3: blankets
column4: change of clothes
column5: and three huge volumes of a financial reference service. Our friends thought a lunacy commission should be appointed.Perhaps they were right. I had had some success at speculation
column6: so we had a little money
column7: but we once worked on a farm for a month to avoid drawing on our small capital. That was the last honest manual labor on my part for many a day. We covered the the whole eastern United States in a year. At the end of it
column8: my reports to Wall Street procured me a position there and the use of a large expense account. The exercise of an option brought in more money
column9: leaving us with a profit of several thousand dollars for that year.

column1: For the next few years fortune threw money and applause my way. I had arrived. My judgment and ideas were followed by many to the tune of paper millions. The great boom of the late twenties was seething and swelling. Drink was taking an important and exhilarating part in my life. There was loud talk in the jazz places uptown. Everyone spent in thousands and chattered in millions. Scoffers could scoff and be damned. I made a host of fair-weather friends.
My drinking assumed more serious proportions
column2: continuing all day and almost every night. The remonstrances of my friends terminated in a row and I became a lone wolf. There were many unhappy scenes in our sumptuous apartment. There had been no real infidelity
column3: for loyalty to my wife
column4: helped at times by extreme drunkenness
column5: kept me out of those scrapes.

column1: In 1929 I contracted golf fever. We went at once to the country
column2: my wife to applaud while I started out to overtake Walter Hagen. Liquor caught up with me much faster than I came up behind Walter. I began to be jittery in the morning. Golf permitted drinking every day and every night. It was fun to carom around the exclusive course which had inspired such awe in me as a lad. I acquired the impeccable coat of tan one sees upon the well-to-do. The local banker watched me whirl fat checks in and our of his till with amused skepticism.

column1: Abruptly in October 1929 hell broke loose on the New York stock exchange. After one of those days of inferno
column2: I wobbled from a hotel bar to a brokerage office. It was eight o'clock - five hours after the market closed. The ticker still clattered. I was staring at an inch of the tape which bore the inscription PKF-32. It had been 52 that morning. I was finished and so were many friends. The papers reported men jumping to death from the towers of High Finance. That disgusted me. I would not jump. I went back to the bar. My friends had dropped several million since ten oclock - so what? Tomorrow was another day. As I drank
column3: the old fierce determination to win came back.

column1: Next morning I telephoned a friend in Montreal. He had plenty of money left and thought I had better go to Canada. By the following spring we were living in our accustomed to style. I felt like Napoleon returning from Elba. No St. Helena for me! But drinking caught up with me again and my generous friend had to let me go. This time we stayed broke.
We went to live with my wife's parents. I found a job; then lost it as the result of a brawl with a taxi driver. Mercifully
column2: no one could guess that I was to have no real employment for five years
column3: or hardly draw a sober breath. My wife began to work in a department store
column4: coming home exhausted to find me drunk. I became an unwelcome hanger-on at brokerage places.

column1: Liquor ceased to be a luxury; it became a necessity. "Bathtub" gin
column2: two bottles a day
column3: and often three
column4: got to be routine. Sometimes a small deal would net a few hundred dollars
column5: and I would pay my bills at the bars and delicatessens. This went on endlessly
column6: and I began to waken very early in the morning shaking violently. A tumbler full of gin followed by half a dozen bottles of beer would be required if I were to eat any breakfast. Nevertheless
column7: I still thought I could control the situation
column8: and there were periods of sobriety which renewed my wife's hope.

column1: Gradually things got worse. The house was taken over by the mortgage holder
column2: my mother-in-law died
column3: my wife and father-in-law became ill.

column1: Then I got a promising business opportunity. Stocks were at the low point of 1932
column2: and I had somehow formed a group to buy. I was to share generously in the profits. Then I went on a prodigious bender
column3: and that chance vanished.

column1: I woke up. This had to be stopped. I saw I could not take so much as one drink. I was through forever. Before then
column2: I had written lots of sweet promises
column3: but my wife happily observed that this time I meant business. And so I did.

column1: Shortly afterward I came home drunk. There had been no fight. Where had been my high resolve? I simply didn't know. It hadn't even come to mind. Someone had pushed a drink my way
column2: and I had taken it. Was I crazy? I began to wonder
column3: for such an appalling lack of perspective seemed near being just that.

column1: Renewing my resolve
column2: I tried again. Some time passed
column3: and confidence began to be replaced by cocksureness. I could laugh at the gin mills. Now I had what it takes! One day I walked into a cafe to telephone. In no time I was beating on the bar asking myself how it happened. As the whiskey rose to my head I told myself I would manage better next time
column4: but I might as well get good and drunk then. And I did.

column1: The remorse
column2: horror and hopelessness of the next morning are unforgettable. The courage to do battle was not there. My brain raced uncontrollably and there was a terrible sense of impending calamity. I hardly dared cross the street
column3: lest I collapse and be run down by an early morning truck
column4: for it was scarcely daylight. An all night place supplied me with a dozen glasses of ale. My writhing nerves were stilled at last. A morning paper told me the market had gone to hell again. Well
column5: so had I. The market would recover
column6: but I wouldn't. That was a hard thought. Should I kill myself? No - not now. Then a mental fog settled down. Gin would fix that. So two bottles
column7: and - oblivion.

column1: The mind and body are marvelous mechanisms
column2: for mine endured this agony for two more years. Sometimes I stole from my wife's slender purse when the morning terror and madness were on me. Again I swayed dizzily before an open window
column3: or the medicine cabinet
column4: where there was poison
column5: cursing myself for a weakling. There were flights from city to country and back
column6: as my wife and I sought escape. Then came the night when the physical and mental torture was so hellish I feared I would burst through my window
column7: sash and all. Somehow I managed to drag my mattress to a lower floor
column8: lest I suddenly leap. A doctor came with a heavy sedative. Next day found me drinking both gin and sedative. This combination soon landed me on the rocks. People feared for my sanity. So did I. I could eat little or nothing when drinking
column9: and I was forty pounds under weight.

column1: My brother-in-law is a physician
column2: and through his kindness I was placed in a nationally-known hospital for the mental and physical rehabilitation of alcoholics. Under the so-called belladonna treatment my brain cleared. Hydrotherapy and mild exercise helped much. Best of all
column3: I met a kind doctor who explained that though certainly selfish and foolish
column4: I had been seriously ill
column5: bodily and mentally.

column1: It relieved me somewhat to learn that in alcoholics the will is amazingly weakened when it comes to combatting liquor
column2: though It often remains strong in other respects. My incredible behavior in the face of a desparate desire to stop was explained. Understanding myself now
column3: I fared forth in high hope. For three or four months the goose hung high. I went to town regularly and even made a little money. Surely this was the answer - self-knowledge.

column1: But it was not
column2: for the frightful day came when I drank once more. The curve of my declining moral and bodily health fell off like a ski-jump. After a time I returned to the hospital. This was the finish
column3: the curtain
column4: it seemed to me. My weary and despairing wife was informed that it would all end with heart failure during delirium tremens
column5: or I would develop a wet brain
column6: perhaps within a year. She would soon have to give me over to the undertaker
column7: or the asylum.

column1: They did not need to tell me. I knew
column2: and almost welcomed the idea. It was a devastating blow to my pride. I
column3: who had thought so well of myself and my abilities
column4: of my capacity to surmount obstacles
column5: was cornered at last. Now I was to plunge into the dark
column6: joining that endless procession of sots who had gone on before. I thought of my poor wife. There had been much happiness after all. What would I not give to make amends. But that was over now.

column1: No words can tell of the loneliness and despair I found in that bitter morass of self-pity. Quicksand stretched around me in all directions. I had met my match. I had been overwhelmed. Alcohol was my master.
Trembling
column2: I stepped from the hospital a broken man. Fear sobered me for a bit. Then came the insidious insanity of that first drink
column3: and on Armistice Day 1934
column4: I was off again. Everyone became resigned to the certainty that I would have to be shut up somewhere
column5: or would stumble along to a miserable end. How dark it is before the dawn! In reality that was the beginning of my last debauch. I was soon to be catapulted into what I like to call the fourth dimension of existence. I was to know happiness
column6: peace
column7: and usefulness
column8: in a way of life that is incredibly more wonderful as time passes.

column1: Near the end of that bleak November
column2: I sat drinking in my kitchen. With a certain satisfaction I reflected there was enough gin concealed about the house to carry me through that night and the next day. My wife was at work. I wondered whether I dared hide a full bottle of gin near the head of our bed. I would need it before daylight.

column1: My musing was interrupted by the telephone. The cheery voice of an old school friend asked if he might come over. He was sober. It was years since I could remember his coming to New York in that condition. I was amazed. Rumor had it that he had been committed for alcoholic insanity. I wondered how he had escaped. Of course he would have dinner
column2: and then I could drink openly with him. Unmindful of his welfare
column3: I thought only of recapturing the spirit of other days. There was that time we had chartered an airplane to complete a jag! His coming was an oasis in this drear desert of futility. The very thing - an oasis! Drinkers are like that.

column1: The door opened and he stood there
column2: fresh-skinned and glowing. There was something about his eyes. He was inexplicably different. What had happened?

column1: I pushed a drink across the table. He refused it. Disappointed but curious
column2: I wondered what had got into the fellow. He wasn't himself.

column1: "Come
column2: what's all this about?" I queried.

column1: He looked straight at me. Simply
column2: but smilingly
column3: he said
column4: "I've got religion."

column1: I was aghast. So that was it - last summer an alcoholic crackpot; now
column2: I suspected
column3: a little cracked about religion. He had that starry-eyed look. Yes
column4: the old boy was on fire all right. But bless his heart
column5: let him rant! Besides
column6: my gin would last longer than his preaching.

column1: But he did no ranting. In a matter of fact way he told how two men had appeared in court
column2: persuading the judge to suspend his commitment. They had told of a simple religious idea and a practical program of action. That was two months ago and the result was self evident. It worked!

column1: He had come to pass his experience along to me - if I cared to have it. I was shocked
column2: but interested. Certainly I was interested. I had to be
column3: for I was hopeless.

column1: He talked for hours. Childhood memories rose before me. I could almost hear the sound of the preacher's voice as I sat
column2: on still Sundays
column3: way over there on the hillside; there was that proffered temperance pledge I never signed; my grandfather's good natured contempt of some church folk and their doings; his insistence that the spheres really had their music; but his denial of the preacher's right to tell him how he must listen; his fearlessness as he spoke of these things just before he died; these recollections welled up from the past. They made me swallow hard.

column1: That war-time day in old Winchester Cathedral came back again.
I had always believed in a power greater than myself. I had often pondered these things. I was not an atheist. Few people really are
column2: for that means blind faith in the strange proposition that this universe originated in a cipher
column3: and aimlessly rushes nowhere. My intellectual heroes
column4: the chemists
column5: the astronomers
column6: even the evolutionists
column7: suggested vast laws and forces at work. Despite contrary indications
column8: I had little doubt that a mighty purpose and rhythm underlay all. How could there be so much of precise and immutable law
column9: and no intelligence? I simply had to believe in a Spirit of the Universe
column10: who knew neither time nor limitation. But that was as far as I had gone.

column1: With ministers
column2: and the world's religions
column3: I parted right there. When they talked of a God personal to me
column4: who was love
column5: superhuman strength and direction
column6: I became irritated and my mind snapped shut against such a theory.

column1: To Christ I conceded the certainty of a great man
column2: not too closely followed by those who claimed Him. His moral teaching - most excellent. For myself
column3: I had adopted those parts which seemed convenient and not too difficult; the rest I disregarded.

column1: The wars which had been fought
column2: the burnings and chicanery that religious dispute had facilitated
column3: made me sick. I honestly doubted whether
column4: on balance
column5: the religions of mankind had done any good. Judging from what I had seen in Europe and since
column6: the power of God in human affairs was negligible
column7: the Brotherhood of Man a grim jest. If there was a Devil
column8: he seemed the Boss Universal
